title: Does the pejorative 'idiot' relate to the psychological analyis of the unconscious mind that the id refers to? Why do we use it to describe someone who has behaved in a way that most find to be foolish or even stupid? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the sense Lacan uses yes, but his use is very peculiar and he prefer its negative form: non-idiot. What is a non-idiot, in the teaching of Lacan? - Any person that, inspite of literacy, is sensible enough to supose the existence of the unconscious as Freud formulated: a language system that precedes us all, traspasses as all, and somehow comands as all against our will. “Psychoanalysis can not be provided for those who are not non-idiots”, he says, because someone that is not a non-idiot (that is: an idiot) can not suppose a knowledge on someone else and hence can never stabilish a transference (with a person or with an institution or a discipline etc). As you can see, than, an idiot is someone that has a presumption of knowledge in themselves, instead of a supposition of knowledge in the Other (culture, nature, civilization, language, the unconscious itself). In this sense, an idiot is not someone that is mentally retarded: Lacan says that Plato, genious in the Symposium (a dialogue precisely about the supposition of knowledge and the sliding place of the truth), is an idiot in the Republic, as in the Republic the tirany he proposes exclude the symbolic order - hence implies an imposition of knowledge (from the Philosopher-King, say) instead of a supposition of knowledge (throu a vote in a democracy, etc). Also, as you can see, because of that an idiot can not take responsibility for their desires and mishappenings - an idiot can not have an effect of subjective rectification. As an idiot has no effect of the symbolic, of the signifier, it is like as if they were reigned completely by the It (id, Es) - an “inhabitant of the id that ignores external reality”. This, as you can see, is similar to the psychodynamics of a psychotic patient - but psychotics are not idiots as they produce and receive a knowledge from the external reality they rejected in the form of delusions, and with this they can become sort of profets instead of idiots (as Schreber says, he is writing precisely to prove to God that he did not become an idiot - about that see the seminars Or worst… and Joyce The Sympthom).

There is no direct connection. Interestingly, however, many pejorative terms started out as non-pejorative terms in psychiatry to describe those with mental deficiency. Imbecile, moron, cretin, retard and idiot were all ‘politically correct’ psychiatric terms before they were (mis)appropriated by the general public. Those with a mental age of less than three years were classed as idiots; those with a mental age of three to seven were imbeciles; those with a mental age of seven to ten were morons. If this sounds ‘bad’ to our modern ears, it’s only because each of these terms has now taken on a pejorative meaning. In their original usage, they were neutral labels. Idiot specifically comes from the Old French idiote (uneducated or ignorant person), which in turn comes from the Latin idiota (ordinary citizen [i.e., presumed illiterate]). It was adopted in English in the 14th century to mean mentally deficient. In 19th- and early 20th-century medicine and psychology, an "idiot" was a person with profound mental deficiency. Only then did it start to creep into common, pejorative use. Id is the Latin word for “it”. This comes from Freud’s psychoanalytic theory of the tension between the conscious self and the power of unconscious instincts. Freud referred to these in German as das Ich und das Es, literally “the I and the it”, but the English translation of 1924 adopted the Latin words for I (ego) and it (id). To the German reader, Freud's original terms are more or less self-explanatory. Their replacement with Latin terms in the English translation has been criticised for being unhelpful.

The word is originally a greek word.  Idio literally means “personal” , “self-same” , “same as ” or “same type”. Idiom (idiomatic) is something typical or characteristic of a group or collective. eg an idiomatic phrase like “He got cold feet” is understood by anyone of a particular culture not to mean literally ‘cold feet’ temperature-wise, but that it means he lost his nerve and didn’t act.  Identity is the id- entity i.e.how an entity sees itself or is recognised (e.g. a policeman might ask “what do you call yourself?”). Although they are often used interchangeably these words have more specific origins. Stupid is from “stupor” and “stupefy” - i.e. sleepy, a stupid person is asleep. A fool is someone gullible.  An idiot is, most literally, someone who mentally is engaged only in their small self-absorbed world, sees things completely subjectively like a solipsist but without any of the practical intelligence that a solipsist might bring to bear. The village idiot is still used as a phrase instead of the “city idiot” because he is considered a small self absorbed person in a community that is itself small and self absorbed !! i.e. hyperbole.

We use it to vent our frustrations with the Alice and Wonderland World in which we are stuck and cannot control or change. When we are happy we won’t use this word but when the endorphins aren’t released and we are grouchy and unpleasant we are likely to vent these negative emotions by referring to others as idiots. We don’t refer to other creatures as idiots; only people. Nor would you call a benefactor an idiot or a policeman on duty or your jailer an idiot unless you had lost your mind and wanted to reveal your complete frustration with yourself.

Ego, super ego, and I'd (the Freudian breakdown) are based in Latin. Ego is your first person pronoun, and “id” is your third person neuter pronoun (it). The idea seems to be to separate those baselines as a lesser “other" that your true self can overcome.Idiot comes from a Greek adjective used to describe a loner/individualist who did not fit into normal communal society. That term was used as a medical diagnosis for humans who seemed mentally incapable of being a productive member of society, and was generalized into the current insult.

The word “idiot” has nothing to do with the psychological term “id,” except in the barest sense. “Idiot” is a word that comes from Ancient Greek, and it meant “common person,” or “lay person,” that is, someone who was unskilled in a certain line of work. As time went on, the meaning moved from “common person” to “rube” and from “lay person” to “ignoramus.” Finally by the Middle Ages it became “someone who is of sub-normal intelligence.” Having moved from Greek to Latin and from Latin to Old French, Middle French and Middle English, the word survives today in its Middle English meaning. You can see the original meaning in our word “idiopathic.”

The origin of the word idiot is not related in any way to the word id. It has always referred to a person of low intelligence. Here is its origin: Middle English (denoting a person of low intelligence) from Old French from Latin idiota ‘ignorant person’, from Greek idiōtēs ‘private person, layman, ignorant person’, from idios ‘own, private’. The word id (the part of the mind in which innate instinctive impulses and primary processes are manifest) was invented in the 1920s: from Latin, literally ‘that’, translating German es . The term was first used in this sense by Freud, following use in a similar sense by his contemporary, Georg Groddeck.

“Id” was a Latinization of the German word “Es” that Freud actually used. Freud’s translator apparently felt that just calling the part of the human psyche the I and the It wasn’t fancy enough, so he introduced the Latin terms we all know so well. “Idiot” originally meant a peasant, a simple, uneducated person. The two words are not related.

In Clinical Psychology, the term “idiot” refers to individuals whose Intelligence Quotient falls below a certain level. The term, however, has evolved into an expletive used when addressing another person deemed to be of inferior mental capacity, particularly after committing an error or misjudgement.

No. “Idiot” is the derived from the Greek word, idios, which means “self” (as is self-evident in the word idiosyncratic). “Id” is derived from the Latin word, id, which means “that” and was used by Freud in place of the the German, es, which means “it” to describe the unconscious, instinctual aspect of the human mind.

To your first question, “no”. It is not related to the Id, Ego, or Super Ego. To your second question, we use this word because it originates from the Greek word idiotes, which, in Greek means "a layman, a person lacking professional skill.

When people refer to somebody as an idiot, they’re not referencing Freudian psychoanalysis. Has nothing to do with that. It has Latin origins. Many of our roots in English derive from Latin. That’s where its meaning originates.
It has no direct relation with either id or unconscious, it is more about being poor at certain cognitive functions, for example being unable to made good judgements of things
